title: Biden Raises Refugee Admissions Cap to 62,500
summary: President had previously faced blowback for backing away from that number. WASHINGTON-President Biden is raising the refugee admissions cap to 62,500 for the rest of this fiscal year, after facing blowback for backing away from that number amid a surge of migrants crossing the southern border illegally.

title: Government Made Missteps in Extending Coronavirus Aid to Trucker, Report Says
summary: Congressional Oversight Commission report suggests inconsistencies in data used to designate Yellow Corp. as critical to national security. The Treasury and Defense departments "made missteps" last year by labeling Yellow Corp. critical to national security, according to a bipartisan congressional panel probing a $700 million coronavirus-relief loan to the financially troubled trucker.

title: Biden's Stimulus for the IRS
summary: More auditors and audits won't yield much new revenue.. President Biden says he wants to "revitalize" IRS enforcement to target wealthy Americans who "aggressively plan to avoid the tax laws." No doubt tax avoiders exist. But a lot less money is likely to be found under the sofa cushions than Mr. Biden and progressives think.

title: Michael Jackson Estate to Face Smaller Tax Bill After Court Ruling
summary: Late singer's name and likeness was worth $4 million at his death, not $161 million IRS estimated, U.S. tax court rules. Michael Jackson's estate prevailed over the Internal Revenue Service on several key issues in a closely watched court case, an outcome that will push the estate's tax burden below the government's initial assessment.

title: Basecamp and the Political Bullies
summary: The company wants an apolitical workplace. Cue the outrage.. Time was when political activism in business was controversial. But in these hyper-political times, refusing to turn your company into a workplace of the woke can make you a target.

title: A Mother's Day Gift Guide to Indulge Her Hobbies
summary: Cultivate the new interests Mom picked up in quarantine (or would have, if she'd had time) with these gifts, from art kits and books to tennis clothes and gardening gear. THE LAST 12 months have been, among other things, the Year of the Hobby.

title: What Was That About Voter Suppression?
summary: Census data show a lower black-white turnout disparity in Georgia than in New Jersey.. 'We have classic voter suppression," declared Kamala Harris last fall, and Democrats keep making the charge. Yet new Census voting data show these claims are as meritless as Donald Trump's that the election was stolen.

title: SmileDirectClub Shares Fall After Firm Reports Cybersecurity Incident
summary: Cyberattack last month disrupted operations and will hurt sales, company says. SmileDirectClub Inc. said a cyberattack last month disrupted the company's operations and will hurt its sales this quarter. The disclosure sent shares lower in after-hours trading.

title: Companies Extend Cloud to the Edge
summary: Firms world-wide on pace to spend $240.6 billion on edge computing through 2024. Companies are expected to raise spending over the next few years on technology designed to power data-processing tools installed directly on factory-floor machinery, cellphone towers, train-track signals or store-checkout hardware-instead of in a data center.

title: Under Armour Paying $9 Million to Resolve SEC Accounting Probe
summary: Regulator claims sportswear brand failed to tell investors that it pulled forward orders to meet quarterly targets. WASHINGTON- Under Armour Inc. agreed to pay $9 million to settle regulatory claims that it failed to disclose that it was pulling forward orders from future quarters, a practice that allowed it to meet Wall Street's revenue estimates.

title: Richard Cordray to Head Student-Loan Agency
summary: Former chief of Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to manage $1.6 trillion borrowing program. The Biden administration named Richard Cordray, the former head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, to oversee the $1.6 trillion federal student-loan program.

title: Hate Crimes in New York City Continue to Rise
summary: Asians were targeted in 80 hate crimes from Jan. 1 through April 4, up from 16 in the same period in 2020, NYPD figures show. Hate crimes in New York City continue to rise, fueled by an increase in crimes targeting Asian-Americans and dozens of crimes against Jews, according to New York Police Department figures released Monday.

title: Youth Pay a High Price for Covid Protection
summary: Leaders' greatest failure was not focusing on the elderly, who had lower costs and far greater benefits.. Now that the Covid-19 pandemic seems to be abating, it's a good time to look at lessons that observers have, or should have, learned. The list of mistakes is long, but the most glaring was the failure to understand and act on the virus's propensity to attack the old and vulnerable. Policy makers failed, in other words, to understand the enemy.

title: I Grieve for My Native India
summary: Being an immigrant once meant leaving your country of birth behind. No longer.. I'm an immigrant, happy and assimilated. I pay closer attention to America than I do to other parts of the world. This isn't only because I live here. Settling in a country calls for integration that is meticulous, not just heartfelt. That doesn't mean that I wall myself off from the world. Like many immigrants, I also pay near-obsessive attention to the land of my birth.

title: Biden's Daycare Plan Is Bad for Families
summary: Young children are clearly happier and healthier when they spend the day at home with a parent.. In his first address to Congress, President Biden proposed spending an extra $225 billion on child care. That's on top of the $40 billion the administration is already spending as part of the "bailout" of child-care providers in Mr. Biden's American Rescue Plan, and the $10.3 billion the federal government normally spends on child-care subsidies. The new plan, billed as an effort to help low- and moderate-income families, would put America on a path to becoming a society where the state assumes much of the care of young children. Many Republicans have balked at the cost of Mr. Biden's spending blowout, but in this case the substance matters more than the money. A dramatic expansion of child care is a bad deal for American parents. More important, it's a bad deal for American children.

title: States Roll Back Restrictions as Covid-19 Cases Decline
summary: Health experts say Americans need to continue to follow public-health guidance and states need to push vaccinations. With more than 40% of all U.S. adults fully vaccinated and the daily number of new Covid-19 cases declining, governors across the U.S. are broadly rolling back restrictions implemented during the pandemic.

title: Who's Afraid of Tim Scott?
summary: The GOP senator forced the president and vice president to respond to him.. Kamala Harris went first. In the Republican response to Joe Biden's address to Congress, Sen. Tim Scott avowed that America "is not a racist country." The next day on ABC's "Good Morning America," the vice president was asked if she agreed with him.

title: Cheer Up About the Middle East
summary: Democracy hasn't advanced, but the U.S. has bolstered its regional interests.. Ten years after Seal Team Six put an end to Osama bin Laden's terrorist career, most observers think of America's 21st-century Middle East policy as a succession of ghastly failures. Certainly ambitious efforts by both Republican and Democratic presidents to transform the region fell far short of success. Yet if the Middle East is less peaceful and no more democratic than it was in 2001, the U.S. has dramatically reduced the ability of regional upheavals to provoke major crises around the world. While withdrawing entirely would be unwise, America can defend its vital interests with less risk and a more focused strategy than at any time since the end of the Cold War.

title: 'The Premonition' Review: A Pandemic of Experts
summary: A band of healthcare elites saw that Covid-19 was more dangerous than U.S. leaders acknowledged. Would their advice have made a difference?. It is an article of faith among America's educated elite that the United States is uniquely bad at solving big problems. Urban sprawl, economic inequality, nuclear proliferation, environmental degradation, whatever-the American intelligentsia can be counted on to conclude that other developed nations handle these perils more judiciously than the U.S. does. You wonder how the country hasn't collapsed under the weight of its own incompetence.

title: Brazil Defends Decision to Reject Russia's Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: Health authority says Russia lacks experience and was defensive in its responses to the agency. SÃO PAULO-Brazil's health authority said it has serious doubts about the safety and efficacy of Russia's Sputnik V Covid-19 vaccine and defended its decision to block the shot for emergency use, saying Russia lacks vaccine experience and was defensive in its responses to the agency.

title: New York, New Jersey Lift Covid-19 Capacity Limits on Businesses
summary: Move is most significant relaxation of restrictions by two states since beginning of pandemic. New York and New Jersey are lifting most capacity limits on businesses put in place last spring to stem the spread of Covid-19 as more people get vaccinated and infections continue to decline.

title: Berkshire Chooses Greg Abel as Warren Buffett's Successor in CEO Role
summary: The choice of Mr. Abel to eventually lead Berkshire Hathaway answers question that had hovered over the firm for decades. Berkshire Hathaway Inc.'s famous Chief Executive Warren Buffett, the billionaire who has led the conglomerate for more than 50 years, is to be succeeded as CEO by vice chairman Greg Abel, putting to rest one of the biggest succession questions in corporate America.

title: Fed's Williams: Fed Far From Achieving Job, Inflation Goals
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of New York's leader says Fed hasn't seen 'nearly enough' good news to change policy stance. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams said Monday that while the U.S. economy is likely to have a very strong year ahead, there isn't yet an imminent need for the central bank to pull back on its aggressive levels of monetary policy support.

title: Is Texas Becoming More Republican?
summary: The GOP wins a 2021 blowout in a competitive 2020 district.. A Texas congressional district that had been trending leftward in recent elections performed a sudden about-face on Saturday in a special election for a U.S. House seat. Though Donald Trump won the state's sixth district by just three points over Joe Biden in November, last weekend none of the Democrats even made it to the finals.

title: Ethereum Is Booming in NFT Frenzy
summary: The gains in ether, the second-largest cryptocurrency by market value behind bitcoin, have accelerated even as bitcoin's momentum slows. The NFT craze has put Ethereum-the blockchain-based computer network that backs it-on the map again, but the platform is already paying for its success.

title: Powell Says Low-Income Lending Rules Should Apply to All Firms
summary: 'Like activities should have like regulation,' Fed chairman says. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said rules on lending in low-income communities should be extended to cover all firms providing consumer credit, not just banks.

title: Dow, S&P 500 Climb to Start May
summary: S&P 500 extends rally after closing April with best one-month performance since November. Investors piled into shares of economically sensitive companies and pulled back from technology stocks Monday, leading to a divergence in major indexes as trading kicked off in May.

title: Landmark Opioid Trial Opens in West Virginia
summary: Trial will be first test of argument that the nation's three largest drug distributors fueled an epidemic of addiction. CHARLESTON, W.Va.-In a highly anticipated trial, lawyers for a West Virginia county and city told a judge Monday that the nation's three largest drug distributors should be held liable for helping spur a public-health crisis by ignoring mounting evidence for years that prescription drugs were being diverted for illegal use.

title: Treasury Expects to Borrow $1.3 Trillion in Second Half of Fiscal 2021
summary: Federal spending expected to pick up following the Covid-19 relief package enacted in March. WASHINGTON-The U.S. plans to borrow nearly $1.3 trillion over the next two quarters as federal spending picks up following the Covid-19 relief package enacted in March, the Treasury Department said Monday.

title: Lumber Prices Break New Records
summary: Sawmill owners poised to reap big profits, while home buyers, renters bear brunt of rising wood costs. The frenzied climb in lumber prices is generating superlative profits for sawmill owners. Home buyers, renters and do-it-yourselfers are footing the bill.

title: EPA Proposes Rules to Curb Air Conditioner Emissions
summary: Proposal is first step toward meeting new mandates to cut supply by 85% over 15 years. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is proposing rules to reduce the use of coolants from air conditioners and refrigerators that are potent greenhouse gases, fulfilling new mandates from Congress with regulations favored by large portions of U.S. industry, according to the agency.

title: 'Latest Record Project: Volume 1' by Van Morrison Review: Songs in the Key of Conspiracy
summary: The singer follows up his anti-lockdown releases with a long album full of more grievances..

title: Chicago Public Schools CEO Janice Jackson to Step Down
summary: The resignation, which comes after Los Angeles superintendent's decision to depart, follows tough year managing Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Verizon to Sell Yahoo, AOL for $5 Billion to Apollo
summary: Wireless giant retreats from digital-media sector in deal with private-equity firm. Apollo Global Management Inc. agreed to pay about $5 billion to acquire Yahoo and AOL from Verizon Communications Inc. as the wireless company exits its ill-fated foray into the media business.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Selections from 'Three' by Stephen Michael King. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Against All Odds (Tuesday Crossword, May 4)
Estee Lauder Stock Was Too Done Up
summary: Makeup sales at the global beauty giant are showing signs of recovery but its shares have priced that in and more. Estee Lauder looks and smells like an obvious beneficiary of the reopening economy. But beauty standards for the company may have been set at unattainable heights.

title: New York City Subway to Return to 24-Hour Service
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo says overnight trains will coincide with May 17 lifting of 12 a.m. curfew on outdoor drinking, dining. New York City's subway will return to 24-hour service on May 17 after a year of nightly shutdowns to clean stations and trains during the Covid-19 pandemic, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Monday.

title: Lemonade CFO Uses Social Media to Connect With Individual Investors
summary: The insurance firm is relying on YouTube and other communication platforms to explain its strategy. Insurance firm Lemonade Inc. is turning to social media channels to communicate with individual investors, a group that has demonstrated its influence in recent months by driving up the price of certain companies' shares.

title: Moderna to Deliver Covid-19 Vaccine to Hard-Hit Developing World
summary: Sale of 34 million doses comes as pandemic rages in countries such as India and Brazil. Moderna Inc. said Monday that it will supply 34 million doses of its Covid-19 vaccine to an international program that distributes free shots to poorer countries.

title: Blue Health Insurers Drop Revenue Rule That Limited Competition
summary: Blue Cross Blue Shield Association implements key aspect of antitrust settlement the companies reached last year. The Blue Cross Blue Shield Association said it dropped a rule that limited competition among its member insurers, moving to implement a key aspect of an antitrust settlement the companies reached last year with customers.

title: Action Network to Be Sold as Sports-Betting Deals Surge
summary: Denmark-based Better Collective to buy U.S. betting-analytics firm for $240 million, seeking more scale in dealings with gambling operators. A wave of deal making is afoot in the sports-betting world, as participants ranging from analytics firms to casinos look to cash in on the growing sector.

title: Legoland Lays Bricks to Transform Quiet New York Town
summary: Theme park is set to bring economic benefits, but some say it will clash with area's semirural atmosphere. GOSHEN, N. Y.-Many of this town's roughly 14,000 residents talk of its quiet, unhurried way of life, almost to the point of poking gentle fun. "Slow-motion Goshen" is how they frequently describe the local pace.

title: Devised for Diabetics, a Glucose Monitor Attracts the Famous and Well-Connected
summary: A continuous sensor points out often-neglected, sometimes dangerous blood-sugar spikes, but critics question its usefulness to the well.

title: The Consequences of Skipping Doctor Appointments During the Covid Pandemic
summary: A year of postponed checkups, mammograms, colonoscopies and other medical care could have serious health repercussions, researchers warn.. Missed checkups and physicals. Delayed mammograms and colonoscopies. Many Americans postponed medical appointments for a year during the pandemic and the impact is just beginning to surface, doctors say.

title: DNB to Be Fined $48.1 Million for Anti-Money-Laundering Inadequacies
summary: The lender acknowledged shortcomings related to customer due diligence and said it has since strengthened efforts to combat money-laundering. DNB AS A on Monday confirmed that Norway's financial supervisory authority, Finanstilsynet, will impose a fine of 400 million Norwegian kroner ($48.1 million) for inadequate compliance with anti-money-laundering rules and legislation.

title: What We Know About India's Covid-19 Variant B.1.617
summary: New versions of the coronavirus took hold after the country relaxed its pandemic control measures. NEW DELHI-Scientists are trying to understand the role coronavirus variants, including a new one known as B.1.617, are playing in the world's fastest-growing surge of Covid-19 cases in India.

title: Apple Has Two Trillion Reasons to Fight for App Store
summary: Service margins are at a record and have been a key underpinning of Apple's surging market value. Apple' s lawyers have an unenviable task: Defending a key underpinning of a $2 trillion enterprise comes with high stakes.

title: Next Generation of Covid-19 Vaccines Could Be a Pill or Spray
summary: Drugmakers and government labs are developing doses easier to take and transport to tackle coronavirus variants and avert future pandemics. The next generation of Covid-19 vaccines in development could come as a pill or a nasal spray and be easier to store and transport than the current handful of shots that form the backbone of the world-wide vaccination effort.

title: How Much Money Do Millennials Make? It's No Longer a Taboo Question
summary: Unlike with previous generations, young adults find it freeing to talk about their personal finances. When 25-year-old Grace Woodward has friends over to her apartment for the first time, they often react to her striking navy-blue walls by asking, "Did your landlord let you paint?"

title: 'Woke' CEOs: Risky Business or the Next Great Awakening?
summary: A debate on corporate leadership and political advocacy.. What business does a CEO have in politics? Many Americans would say none, but corporations have interests and it is not only the right but the duty of chief executives to advance them, including through the political process. Yet there's a reason they tend to do so quietly: Too much publicity risks drawing the ire of Americans who worry that public policy is warped for private advantage. But today, major CEOs have embarked on a most unusual political intervention. They have taken high-profile positions on a controversial issue that seems to have very little to do with their bottom lines.

title: Los Angeles Times Picks ESPN's Kevin Merida as Next Top Editor
summary: Veteran newspaper journalist has led the Undefeated, a website focused on race, sports and culture. The Los Angeles Times named Kevin Merida as its new executive editor, as the publication looks to raise its profile and jump-start digital growth.

title: Media Mistrust Won't Inoculate You Against Misinformation
summary: The impressions we form about important events will still be driven by their unreliable reporting.. It's easy to become inured to the daily procession of flagrant falsehoods, tendentious misrepresentations, deceitful exaggerations and narrative-driven editorial distortions from many of the nation's leading media outlets. As opinion surveys suggest that most of these organizations now rank in public trust a little below emailed pleas from deposed Nigerian princes, it's easy to think the power they once wielded has been so diminished that they are little more than a mildly diverting source of contemporary color in our lives.

title: Amazon to Get Exclusive NFL Rights a Year Earlier Than Expected
summary: Tech giant's 'Thursday Night Football' deal will start in 2022-23, as Fox exits its pact early. Amazon . com Inc. will take over exclusive video rights for "Thursday Night Football" starting in the 2022-23 season, a year earlier than anticipated, the company and the National Football League said Monday.

title: The CEO of Ben & Jerry's Wants to Redefine the C-Suite
summary: As the head of the ice cream maker, Matthew McCarthy sees business as a force for social change, and believes the next generation of leaders will too. Author

title: Can the USPS Deliver a Major Reformation?
summary: Fix the price structure first.. The Greeting Card Association agrees with your editorial "How to Save the Post Office, Maybe" (April 27) that postal-reform legislation is urgently needed, but differs on what that reform should entail. The USPS is now trending toward a far smaller loss than projected earlier this year, as the improving economy has brought more mail and packages into the system. The USPS plan correctly establishes a break-even proposition, but as USPS finances improve, so should postage rates.

title: U.S. Vets Rate the Afghanistan Withdrawal
summary: In a war that has lasted almost 20 years with no victory and none in sight, why do we think we need more time?. Veterans are understandably weary of American efforts in Afghanistan, but there are a few critical lessons we should keep in mind ("Vets See Echoes of Vietnam in Afghanistan Withdrawal Plan," Page One, April 27).

title: A Federal Plan to End Our Environmental Plasticide
summary: Only 9% of plastic waste is ever recycled, and much of our plastic isn't recyclable anyway.. Jo Craven McGinty's column "The Numbers: This Plastic Recyclable? Depends on the Sort?" (U.S. News, April 24) could have been called "Here's Why Recycling Doesn't Work." Despite the plastics industry's convincing consumers for decades that plastic pollution would disappear if they just recycled more effectively, the truth is in the numbers. Only 9% of plastic waste is ever recycled, and much of our plastic isn't recyclable anyway.

title: Yellen to Appoint Senior Fed Official to Run Top Bank Regulator
summary: Michael Hsu is expected to become acting comptroller of the currency. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen plans to appoint one of the Federal Reserve's top big-bank supervisors to become the acting comptroller of the currency, overseeing the country's largest financial firms, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Digital-Health Startups Are Booming. Their Customers Are Overwhelmed.
summary: As investors pour money into health startups, customers press for price breaks and streamlining; 'We are inundated'. Digital-health startups have boomed during the pandemic, raising record amounts of capital for a range of services. The message from some of their customers: Enough, already.

title: Teen Girls' Poor Diets Are Worrying Doctors
summary: Many adolescent girls aren't getting enough important nutrients, which could lead to poor school performance, future health issues. Doctors and nutrition experts are increasingly alarmed by the widespread low intake of key nutrients among preteen and teen girls, and are warning that poor diets are likely to cause both immediate issues such as poor school performance and long-term health problems like osteoporosis.

title: Medical Expenses and Taxes: What You Need to Know
summary: How to handle unreimbursed medical expenses on your tax returns can be confusing. Don't leave money on the table.. Medical-expense deductions, once on the congressional chopping block, are alive and well, including a recent newcomer stemming from the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Pressure Intensifies on Manchester United Owners After Violent Protest
summary: Fan groups redoubled their efforts to force change within the club as police investigate Sunday's events at Old Trafford. Manchester United supporters intensified the pressure on the club's American owners on Monday with demands that they reduce their stake in the club, just one day after a large-scale protest outside the team's Old Trafford stadium turned violent and saw hundreds of fans break onto the field.

title: Investment Crowdfunding: Is Buying $100 in Equity in Your Favorite Shoe Brand Worth It?
summary: Season Three, a New York boot company, is raising capital via Republic, an investment crowdfunding website that allows backers of the brand to acquire a small sliver of the company itself. ETHAN BOYE-DOE has purchased several pairs of boots-for himself, his father and a nephew-from Season Three, a year-old New York hiking boot company. Last month, Mr. Boye-Doe, 30, a product manager at Spotify in New York, put his money toward something else that Season Three was shilling: a piece of the company. He invested a few hundred dollars in the enterprise (roughly the price of a single pair of boots) via Republic, a five-year-old investment crowdfunding website based in New York that offers independent investors the opportunity to acquire a small sliver of a company.

title: North Korea's Kim Il Sung Has a Memoir. South Koreans Aren't Allowed to Buy It.
summary: Bookstores have halted sales, and police are investigating after a small publisher released it. SEOUL-Bookstores have halted sales of a memoir by North Korea's founding father, and local police are investigating its distribution in South Korea, in the latest of a series of free-speech controversies relating to the Kim regime.

title: A 7-foot Bird Tests the Limits of Tolerance in New Orleans
summary: Free-roaming peacock pecks at cars, leaves messes and 'either honks like a goose or heehaws like a donkey when he's upset'. NEW ORLEANS-Nobody knows how or why Mr. P came to live in Pigeon Town, except maybe to show off.

title: Auto Makers Retreat From 50 Years of 'Just in Time' Manufacturing
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO- Toyota Motor Corp. is stockpiling up to four months of some parts. Volkswagen AG is building six factories so it can get its own batteries. And, in shades of Henry Ford, Tesla Inc. is trying to lock up access to raw materials.

title: Meredith Exiting Local TV Business in $2.7 Billion Deal
summary: Company says deal with Gray Television would allow it to better focus on magazine brands, digital-media properties. Meredith Corp. is selling its broadcast-television business to Gray Television Inc., in a deal the company said would allow it to better focus on its magazine brands and digital-media properties.

title: Blackstone Elevates New Generation of Private-Equity Leaders
summary: Appointments are sign of unit's growing heft. Blackstone Group Inc. is elevating a number of longtime staffers to new leadership roles in its main private-equity business, in a sign of the growing heft of the unit in which the investment giant cut its teeth 36 years ago.

title: Tim Scott Sets Off New Round in Unfinished Race Conversation
summary: The terms of the conversation have changed, separating Americans along not just racial lines but generational ones as well. The great unfinished conversation in America is the one about race.

title: In L.A. and San Francisco, Schools Are Open but Classrooms Are Near-Empty
summary: Resume Subscription. When Siniya Longino arrived for her first day of in-person eighth grade in San Francisco last week, there was only one other student in the classroom. Everyone else was remote, as were all of her teachers. Siniya logs into Zoom on her laptop from her desk to see them.

title: You Don't Want Your Heirs to Fight Over Your Assets? Here's What to Do Now.
summary: It's the day-to-day items-the ones with sentimental value-that can cause the most problems. I would like to see you write about the best way to divide up treasured items among family members when someone dies-including the items that probably no one will want.

title: What Business Thinks of Biden's Plans on Infrastructure, Taxes
summary: Proposals to boost infrastructure spending welcomed, but companies wary of higher taxes and new regulations.

title: SpaceX Capsule Returns to Earth in Rare Nighttime Splashdown
summary: Capsule returned from the International Space Station, landed safely in the Gulf of Mexico. A SpaceX capsule with four astronauts returning from the International Space Station splashed down safely in the Gulf of Mexico early Sunday , the first such nighttime return to Earth for NASA in decades.

title: Tesla, Berkshire Hathaway, Moderna: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Shares of Covid-19 vaccine makers are rising in premarket trading. By Anna Hirtenstein

title: Fund Companies Push Diversity in Bond Trading
summary: Electronic-trading platform MarketAxess is helping large asset managers meet requirements to transact more with minority-owned dealers. Some of the biggest bond fund managers in the U.S. are using technology to increase the business they do with broker-dealers owned by women and members of minority groups.

title: Bill Nye Owns Three Coffee Machines and Over 500 Bow Ties
summary: The Science Guy also tells us about not taking vitamins and why we all might be descendants of Martians.. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: Covid-19 Vaccinations Are Slowing, So Officials Target Markets, Schools
summary: States are also offering incentives, from cash to free drinks. There are 15 different places to get a Covid-19 vaccine in Louisiana's Vernon Parish. Most locations have plenty of shots, and residents can even stop by the fairgrounds for one of the pop-up vaccine clinics.

title: Some Countries Threaten Citizens With Jail if They Return From India
summary: Australia says violators of travel ban could face five years' imprisonment after New Zealand eases a similar Covid-19 restriction. SYDNEY-The wave of Covid-19 sweeping India is leading some nations that have largely contained the virus to threaten their own citizens with jail time or heavy fines if they try to get home from the South Asian country.

title: Modi's BJP Suffers Setback in West Bengal State Elections
summary: State's governing Trinamool Congress party was on track early Monday to win as many as 213 seats in the state legislature. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party fell far short in its attempt to win control in a fiercely contested state election, one in which its aggressive efforts to get out the vote have been criticized as worsening the country's surge in Covid-19 infections.

title: Aaron Rodgers, Broncos QB? Stay in GB? 'Jeopardy!' Host?
summary: The reigning NFL MVP is reportedly looking to move onto a new team. Or, alternatively, a full-time game show career.. Let's begin by reminding everyone that Aaron Rodgers is very, very good at this. He knows the game cold, he's quick on his feet, he does his homework, he respects the history and tradition of the position-and he wishes not merely to impress, but to be the best, for a long, long time.

title: Daniel Humm's New Eleven Madison Park Menu Will Be Meat-Free
summary: Humm's Michelin three-starred Eleven Madison Park almost never had an empty table. Will going almost fully vegan be his biggest-ever test?. Just before 8 p.m., on a Tuesday evening in April, in the massive steel-and-marble kitchen of New York's Eleven Madison Park, Daniel Humm's team of chefs perfected the beet. It was a giddy moment. The beet-at first glance-looks like a regular old cooked beet. But when you bite into it, the taste is, all at once, smoky and sweet and acidic and earthy, and there is a rich, creamy texture alongside a hint of crunch. The tastes themselves are incredible, but so is the simple fact of this dish. How in the world can a beet be so complex, so surprising, yet also so authentically beety?

title: Bidenomics Takes Root in Europe's Economically Fragile South
summary: Italy, Spain and Greece plan to revamp their economies. If it doesn't work, a mountain of debt could revive eurozone tensions.. ROME-The global policy trend of heavy fiscal stimulus, led by the U.S., faces a test case in Southern Europe.

title: Michael Lewis's 'The Premonition': A Closer Look at How the Pandemic Response Went Awry
summary: In 'The Premonition: A Pandemic Story,' the bestselling author offers another timely parable that stirs the pot-and again puts the moral of the story in his characters' hands.. Early in The Premonition: A Pandemic Story, Michael Lewis's new nonfiction book recounting how the foresight of a small group of people culminated in breakthrough strategies for containing Covid-19, Charity Dean, Santa Barbara County's newly appointed public health officer, senses there might be an outbreak of airborne tuberculosis, an easily transmittable illness that often spreads in hard-to-trace ways. (Until Covid-19, tuberculosis had been the world's leading cause of death from an infectious agent.) To grasp the extent of the threat, Dean hopes to examine a bit of lung tissue from a young woman who has just died, in December of 2014, but she's thwarted by a grouchy, 70-something local coroner. After appealing to the sheriff, Dean is allowed to biopsy the lung. The coroner refuses to help with the procedure and instead hands her a pair of gardening shears, hoping to deter her. Repressing nausea while standing over the body, Dean cuts out the lung herself in front of the astonished coroner, sheriff and a few of his deputies, tosses it into an orange Home Depot bucket and drives away.

title: As Covid Testing Moves Center Stage, U.S. and U.K. Approaches Differ
summary: U.K. provides centralized free testing while the U.S. is patchy, less intensive. LONDON-As successful vaccination drives beat back Covid-19 in many Western countries, health experts say quicker and smarter testing is the route to keeping the disease under control as restrictions on daily life ease.

title: Fidelity Halves Its Ant Group Valuation After Beijing's Clampdown
summary: Asset manager marked Ant shares in several of its funds at prices that implied a $144 billion valuation at the end of February. U.S. mutual-fund giant Fidelity Investments has drastically changed its view of what Jack Ma's Ant Group Co. is worth after China's regulatory crackdown on the financial-technology giant severely dented its growth prospects.

title: Asia's Lopsided Economic Booms Store Problems for the Future
summary: Export-focused growth is making financial vulnerabilities worse for Taiwan and South Korea. South Korea and Taiwan both reported better-than-expected economic growth last week, and in both cases it looks quite similar: Exports have boomed, domestic demand hasn't. That has already caused some problems, which will be exacerbated if the trend continues unabated.

title: How Microsoft's Chief Accessibility Officer Does Her Job
summary: Jenny Lay-Flurrie holds every department-from hiring to videogaming-accountable for being accessible to people with disabilities. Microsoft Corp. last week announced steps it plans to take in the next five years to improve accessibility to people with disabilities, promising to ramp up its development of related technology, create opportunities for more of them to enter the workforce and make its own workplace more inclusive for them.

title: A Record Share of Companies Are Beating Earnings Estimates
summary: Investors wonder how much results have already been baked into share prices. Corporate earnings have rarely looked this good.

title: Warren Buffett Says Bad Leaders Pose Biggest Risk to Companies
summary: Berkshire Hathaway CEO warns that business failures can occur if personable managers 'put on an appearance' of competence. Poor management is the top threat facing companies, according to Warren Buffett, who spoke out on the issue over the weekend.

title: Brexit: What to Know About the U.K.'s Deal With the EU
summary: New arrangements came into force on Jan. 1, 2021. Brexit is shorthand for Britain's exit from the European Union, which took place on Jan. 31, 2020, following a referendum in June 2016. The EU was left as 27 countries and a combined population of almost 450 million people that share a set of rules and laws covering the economy, trade and legal and security cooperation. The bloc grew out of a grouping of six countries that sought economic cooperation in the years after World War II. Britain joined the bloc in 1973, along with Ireland and Denmark.

title: How to Plug Into Electric-Vehicle Chargers
summary: Chargers may prove better investments than many EV makers, but stock pickers still need to choose between a plethora of business models. Among the picks and shovels in the electric-vehicle boom are charging points. They seem to be more reliable bets than the startup car brands looking to take on Tesla , but investors still need to decide whether they prefer picks, shovels or something altogether new.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Shift Key (Monday Crossword, May 3)
Dell Reaches Deal to Sell Boomi to TPG, Francisco Partners
summary: Transaction values the cloud-based integration platform at $4 billion including debt. Dell Technologies Inc. struck a deal to sell its Boomi cloud business to private-equity firms Francisco Partners and TPG, part of a larger reordering of the PC and data-storage giant.

title: Suspected Migrant-Packed Vessel Capsizes Near San Diego, Leaving Three Dead
summary: Deaths come as authorities increase efforts to combat smuggling migrants by sea. A vessel authorities believe was illegally smuggling migrants into the U.S. capsized Sunday off the coast of San Diego with at least 30 people on board, leading to three deaths, authorities said.

title: Voters Choose Two Republicans to Compete for Texas House Seat
summary: Susan Wright, widow of Rep. Ron Wright, will face state Rep. Jake Ellzey, in a runoff. Voters in a Texas House district chose two Republicans to advance to a runoff election, dashing Democratic hopes of picking up a GOP-held seat.

title: The Pandemic Prompted Them to Return Home-Now They're Staying
summary: Many young adults who left for different lives in new cities have found comfort in changing their plans and putting down roots closer to family. Megan Riner was living alone in a tiny studio apartment in Portland, Ore., when the pandemic hit. Working the overnight shift at a television news station made it tough to find friends. After her job went virtual because of Covid, she rarely left her apartment, exacerbating her sense of isolation.
